evidence.pdf_reference: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to solar fuels is considered as a promising strategy to address the global warming and energy shortages.Herein, a novel method is proposed to prepare g-C 3 N 4 ZnO nanocomposites via refluxing zinc salt methanol solution containing pre-formed g-C 3 N 4 with KOH methanol solution as precipitating agent.Some in-situ grown ultrafine ZnO nanoparticles are decorated on ultrathin g-C 3 N 4 layers with well-defined interface, which not only causes efficient charge transfer and

water and KOH aqueous solution instead of the methanol and KOH methanol solution, only delivers trace photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity with CH 4 CO generation rates of 0.71.2mol g -1 h -1 and a TCEN value of 8.0 mol g -1 h -1 , which is much lower than those of the CZ-40 composite.It implies that the hard aggregation (Fig. S2) of ZnO in the CZ-40aq composite would not beneficial for the visible light absorption of the co-existed g-C 3 N 4 , and thus causing the trace activity.On the other hand, those

(MIM) mode to record the mass signals of CO 2 (mz 44) and H 2 O (mz 18). The photocatalytic experiments were carried out in a closed glass reactor with a volume of 500 mL under the illumination of a 300 W Xelamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 420 nm).Typically, photocatalyst (60 mg) was evenly dispersed on a watch glass with an area of 28 cm 2 , which was placed on a holder in the reactor, and then NaHCO 3 (1.60 g) was introduced into the bottom of the reactor.After the air was completely removed by

ability to H 2 O is higher than that of the single ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 , which is similar to that of the CO 2 desorption mentioned above. The above results suggest that the hybridization between ultrathin g-C 3 N 4 layers and ZnO nanoparticles improves the CO 2 H 2 O chemisorption capacity, which plays a vital role in the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process.The more effective H 2 OCO 2 chemisorption of the CZ-40 composite may be a benefit to the proton-coupled-electron-transfer (PCET) process for CO 2
